1) Consider the base rate.  The present law has been in place since 1973.  In the time between then and now, spot oil prices got as high as $150/barrel.  There was a significant depression in the oil industry in the mid-80s.  Through these extremes, this law has not been withdrawn.  IMO, it has been US policy that oil is a strategic commodity, and that exporting refined products is better business.  This has been consistent across time and administrations.

This Q doesn't close until April. Sometimes, but not always, there is a bit of a scramble to clear out the possibly controversial underbrush early in an election-year session. This is because voters are believed to have the attention span of puppies.  Sometimes the magic works and sometimes it doesn't, but this is the sort of issue I think will be dealt with quickly and quietly in February or March, probably as a rider on something else. (Remember that the US Congress, unlike civilized legislatures, does not require amendments to be germane to the bill's topic.)

Following Jean-Pierre downward by 5%. I would have gone lower but was dissuaded by walt's excellent analysis and link and the relatively long forecast horizon. Fellow forecasters take note: Jean Pierre has been doing extraordinarily well so far.

HR 702 passed the House on Oct 9 with 137 co-sponsors. (The vote was 261-159 with 26 Democrats joining the majority.) As of Oct 19 it is in the Senate Banking committee. On Oct 1, that same Senate committee bumped a scheduled Treasury nomination in order to mark up a similar bill that originated in the Senate. I'm interpreting that as a signal from Chairman Shelby that other business will be slowed in favor of 702. This bill is the fastest and easiest route to the president's desk since the thing has already passed the House. The various amendments to other bills that have cropped up here and there with the same objective are a form of covering fire, a signal to opponents that you might as well bring 702 to the floor because we'll just bring up the issue as smaller caliber amendments on everything else.

"End of the road for oil exports on highway bill": http://fuelfix.com/blog/2015/11/04/end-of-the-road-for-oil-exports-on-highway-bill/

"The House is set to vote on lifting a 40-year-old ban on crude oil exports next week, after scrapping a tentative plan to do so before the end of September.
A spokesman for House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy confirmed the plan in a two-word email response to the Washington Examiner: "next week."
...
The Senate is pushing forward with its own bill, which was passed out of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee in July along a strict party-line vote. But that's not the only bill out there. The Senate Banking Committee is taking up a bill introduced by Democrat Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, which could bring more support from the minority party.
The committee is expected to vote on the bill Thursday, moving two bills to the Senate floor for consideration. It is not known when the bill will come up for a vote. Senate leadership has been coy on the legislation, as many analysts and observers say it faces an uphill battle there."

This is on its way to the Foreign Affairs committee before it goes to the House. Congressman Scott Perry provided this summary to their April meeting:

Extractors have a lot of capital tied up in idle rigs in the Bakken and West Texas, rigs that they bought not too long ago. There are two really nice graphs here
http://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.cfm?id=22992
that I can't seem to copy over to this box, so here it is in duller words. Debt service for on-shore drillers was 80% of cash flow in 2Q of 2015, 75% in 1Q. Interest rates for bonds in the energy sector have been above 10% since July in an environment where Bloomberg's HIGH YIELD corporate bond index has been pretty steady at 6%. This all says that US oil is in pain and the situation is pretty unsustainable for them. On that kind of margin, with oil prices low for the foreseeable future, the only way for drillers to keep paying the bills is to start up those idle rigs again, and that requires an expanded market.

Based on two articles from the website "The Hill", implementation of lifting the ban appears to have significant support by Republicans (majority w/in House and Senate). Additionally, with President Obama's past veto of the Keystone Pipeline, it would appear that agreeing to lift the ban might make some political hay between his administration and the Republicans. WIth the Russian's continued effort w/respect to exploiting the Arctic (outpacing every other member in the Arctic Council's eight nations), it would stand to reason that the U.S. develop agreements with those in need before other nations beat us to the punch. Alternatively, this might not be necessary as petroleum prices continue to decline due to increased supply/decreasing demand/renewable's.  In the end, lifting the export ban would benefit the U.S. in the long-term, so I see it happening more than I don't see it happening.  If history is any indicator, oil prices will rise once again...

I don't think this is a matter of whether preferences align such that a majority of both chambers support the policy, but rather whether 1) Congress can function in the coming months (i.e. if Congress cannot stave off a shutdown, nothing else on the agenda will be considered for that duration), 2) the Senate can secure cloture, and 3) the policy is salient enough for both chambers of Congress to go through the process of passing this legislation.

http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/17/us-usa-oilexports-house-idUSKCN0RH26Z20150917
"A bill to repeal the 40-year-old ban on U.S. oil exports easily passed the energy panel in the House of Representatives on Thursday, but the measure faces an uphill battle in the Senate.
The legislation, which passed 31 to 19, is expected to be passed by the full House in coming weeks.
...
And a similar bill in the Senate faces an uncertain future because backers need the support of several Democrats to ensure its passage.
...
Democrats who voted against the bill said they were concerned about the environmental consequences of increased domestic oil drilling and the possible loss of jobs at refineries and in shipbuilding.

http://www.wsj.com/articles/house-plans-vote-on-bill-to-lift-ban-on-oil-exports-1442329626
"House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R., Calif.) announced the vote, which is being scheduled for the last week of September, at a Tuesday speech before the Houston-area Chamber of Commerce. While the legislation is likely to pass the GOP-controlled House, its prospects in the Senate are less clear, and the White House said it opposes it.
...
Mr. McCarthy is scheduling the vote for the last week of September, but fights over unrelated spending issues could push the vote on oil exports by a week or two, according to GOP House aides. 
...
A Senate panel voted earlier this summer on similar legislation to lift the oil-export ban, but no Democrats supported the measure. That bodes poorly for its prospects before the full Senate, should it come up for a vote at all in the coming weeks.
A spokeswoman for Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.), whose office controls the floor schedule in the Senate, declined to comment. Mr. McConnell hasn’t weighed in on the topic publicly."

At the moment nobody opposes relaxing the ban except for the occasional isolationist knuckle-dragger who doesn't need campaign contributions from oil firms. However, oil prices are funny things, and short-term fluctuations often drive political decisions with long-term consequences.

With US production starting to decline, the expected surplus for export may no longer be there. The demand for relaxation was much more urgent last year. However, it's very likely that legislation making its way through Congress will pass by the due date, as there doesn't seem to be any serious opposition to it.
